Authors: Bek J., Opluštil S., Drábková J., Pšenička J.
Title: The sub-arborescent lycopsid Omphalophloios feistmantelii (O. Feistmantel) comb. nov. emend. from the Middle Pennsylvanian of the Czech Republic
Affiliations: Department of Palaeoecology and Palaeobiology, Institute of Geology v.v.i., Academy of Sciences, Rozvojová 269, Prague 6, Czech Republic; Faculty of Sciences, Charles University, Albertov 6, Prague 1, Czech Republic; Czech Geological Survey, Klárov, Prague 1, Czech Republic; West Bohemian Museum, Kopeckého sady 357/2, Pilsen, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Bek, J., Department of Palaeoecology and Palaeobiology, Institute of Geology v.v.i., Academy of Sciences, Rozvojová 269, Prague 6, Czech Republic; Opluštil, S., Faculty of Sciences, Charles University, Albertov 6, Prague 1, Czech Republic; Drábková, J., Czech Geological Survey, Klárov, Prague 1, Czech Republic; Pšenička, J., West Bohemian Museum, Kopeckého sady 357/2, Pilsen, Czech Republic
Abstract: About ninety compression specimens of sub-arborescent lycopsid Sporangiostrobus feistmantelii (Feistmantel) Němejc from the middle Westphalian strata of central and western Bohemia, Czech Republic, were studied. A new combination, Omphalophloios feistmantelii (O. Feistmantel) comb. nov. emend., is proposed and the original diagnosis is emended, mainly by new data concerning spores, sporangia, vegetative and reproductive parts. The basal vegetative part of the stem bears rhomboidal leaf cushions with bell-shaped leaf scars, although a larger part of the stem consists of a fertile axis bearing oval sporangia about 5–6mmwide and 7–8mmlong. O. feistmantelii is estimated to be a plant of about 2 to 3 m in height of columnar habit sometimes once or twice dichotomizing in the fertile part of the stem. The fertile zone matured from bottom to top shedding first more than 20 cm long grass-like laminae and than ripened sporangia, leaving only pedicels on the naked axis (Puertollania-disarticulation stage). This suggests continuous reproduction from the time the plant reached the mature stage at the end of its life cycle. The older decorticated part of the stem displays the Knorria-type of preservation. In situ microspores possess large morphological variation and can be assigned to the genera Densosporites (Berry) Butterworth et al. and Cristatisporites (Potonié & Kremp) Butterworth et al. In situ megaspores are of the Zonalesporites superbus-type. The stratification of sporangial walls is described from cuticle studies. O. feistmantelii is interpreted as a plant having an opportunistic life strategy and was able to colonize rapidly local habitats, particularly where there was limited competition, preferring peat and mixed peat-clastic swamps. © 2015, Czech Geological Survey. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cuticle analysis; Densospores; In situ spores; Lycopsids; Omphalophloios; Palaeoecology; Pennsylvanian; Sporangiostrobus; Superbisporites
Index Keywords: cuticle; leaf; life cycle; morphology; paleoecology; Pennsylvanian; spore; stem; Bohemia; Czech Republic; Lycopodiopsida

Authors: Bieňkowska-Wasiluk M., Bonde N.
Title: A new oligocene relative of the caproidae (teleostei: Acanthopterygii) from the outer Carpathians, Poland
Affiliations: University of Warsaw, Žwirki i Wigury 93, Warszawa, Poland; Zoological Museum (SNM), Universitetsparken 15, DK-2100 Copenhagen 0, Denmark, and Fur Museum (Muserum Sailing), Fur, Nederby, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Bieňkowska-Wasiluk, M., University of Warsaw, Žwirki i Wigury 93, Warszawa, Poland; Bonde, N., Zoological Museum (SNM), Universitetsparken 15, DK-2100 Copenhagen 0, Denmark, and Fur Museum (Muserum Sailing), Fur, Nederby, Denmark
Abstract: The osteology of Caprosimilis carpathicus gen. et sp. nov., from the Early Oligocene Menilite beds of the Outer Carpathians, Poland, is described. This taxon possesses a unique combination of features that supports its recognition as a new genus of the superorder Acanthopterygii. It is characterized by: deep body, posterior part of frontals ornamented with curving ridges and spines, eight branchiostegal rays, 24 vertebrae (10 abdominal), ossified ribs present on 4th to 10th abdominal vertebrae, nine spines and 21 soft rays in dorsal fin, four spines and 18 soft rays in anal fin, three anal-fin pterygiophores in first interhaemal space (between haemal spines of first and second caudal vertebrae), three supernumerary spines on first radial of anal fin. Caprosimilis carpathicus gen. et sp. nov. is compared with extant genera of Caproidae (Antigonia and Capros), Zeiformes (Cyttus and Oreosoma) and Tetraodontiformes (Parahollardia), and with the Early Eocene genera Protozeus, Acanthonemus and Zorzinichthys to access its phylogenetic position. A phylogenetic analysis indicates that C. carpathicus gen. et sp. nov. is a close relative of the Caproidae. © 2015, Czech Geological Survey. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Caprosimilis carpathicus gen. et sp. nov; Comparative osteology; Menilite beds; Phylogenetic analysis; Zeomorpha
Index Keywords: new genus; Oligocene; osteology; paleontology; phylogenetics; taxonomy; teleost; Carpathians; Poland; Acanthopterygii; Antigonia; Caproidae; Capros; Cyttus; Oreosoma; Parahollardia; Teleostei; Tetraodontiformes; Zeiformes
